ğŸ“° dbushell.com (all feeds) (1 article)

â–¸ https://dbushell.com/notes/2026-01-29T07:35Z/

ğŸ’¡ Tech companies ignore overwhelming user rejection of AI features (90% in polls), prioritizing financial narratives over user-centered design principles.

# Summary This article critiques the tech industry's dismissal of user preferences regarding AI integration, citing polls from Firefox and DuckDuckGo showing approximately 90% of users reject AI features. Despite overwhelming negative feedback, software companies continue pushing AI implementations while disregarding user-centered design principles, instead telling users what they need rather than listening to their concerns. The author identifies "AI Inevitablism" as a financially-driven narrative that frames AI adoption as unstoppable and inevitable, while users who resist are dismissed as luddites. The piece questions whether companies will honor promises like Mozilla's "off switch" and highlights a broader trend of AI non-consent, suggesting this narrative's persistence depends entirely on continued funding rather than genuine user demand.

ğŸ“ å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹ (5 sections)
  • User Polling Results: Firefox and DuckDuckGo both conducted polls showing users overwhelmingly reject AI features. DuckDuckGo's poll revealed approximately 90% of voters don't want AI integration.
  • Corporate Response Concerns: Despite negative user feedback, questions remain whether companies will actually listen to their users. Mozilla has promised an off switch, but AI non-consent is becoming a growing trend.
  • End of UX: Software companies no longer prioritize listening to users or caring about their needs. Users are told what they like and need, rather than being consulted.
  • Luddite Accusations: Users who reject AI features are dismissed as luddites and accused of being "behind the times." This represents a shift away from user-centered design principles.
  • AI Inevitablism: The concept of "AI Inevitablism" describes the narrative that AI is permanent and unstoppable, backed by massive financial investment. This narrative persists only as long as funding continues.

ğŸ“° Adactio (2 articles)

â–¸ You Can Just Say No to the Data - Jim Nielsenâ€™s Blog

ğŸ’¡ Data reveals what users do, not what companies should doâ€”ethical product decisions require human judgment beyond algorithmic predictions.

# Summary This article argues that data-driven decision-making is often used to abdicate ethical responsibility rather than provide genuine justification for product choices. The author contends that demand can be artificially manufactured through algorithms and dark patterns, making appeals to "giving users what they want" fundamentally flawed. While data effectively answers "what is happening," it cannot address "what should happen"â€”questions of ethics, values, and vision that require human judgment. The core message is that developers and creators have both the agency and responsibility to reject data-driven suggestions when they conflict with ethical considerations, as prediction of user behavior doesn't create an obligation to act on it.

ğŸ“ å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹ (8 sections)
  • Data Doesn't Justify: Using data to justify actions is an attempt at exoneration rather than a valid reason to exist. The cigarette industry example illustrates how demand alone doesn't make something right or worthwhile.
  • Engineered Demand Problem: Demand can be artificially created through algorithms, dark patterns, and growth hacking. Claiming to "give people what they want" ignores how desire is actively shaped and manipulated.
  • Data as Abdication: Appealing to data as ultimate authority, especially when demand is engineered, represents an abdication of responsibility rather than neutrality. It's a way to avoid making ethical decisions.
  • Higher Aspirations Needed: Simply satisfying human desire is not the highest aspiration for builders and creators. We are capable of doing much more than merely supplying what data indicates is in demand.
  • Values Over Data: Data reveals what people consume, not what you should create. Values, ethics, and vision are necessary to answer the "should" question that data cannot address.
  • Different Questions Require Different Approaches: "What is happening?" and "What should happen?" are fundamentally different questions. They require separate frameworks and should not be conflated or treated identically.
  • Power Demands Responsibility: The more powerful our ability to understand and predict demand becomes, the more important our responsibility to decide whether to respond to it. We have the agency to say no to data-driven suggestions.
  • Choosing What to Profit From: Data can predict user behavior and clicks, but creators retain the power and responsibility to decide what they will actually build and profit from. Prediction doesn't equal obligation.

ğŸ’¡ "Chaser Game" Season 2 side story released, exploring President Nishikawa's struggles; creator Matsuyama launches game industry guide for CyberConnect2's 30th anniversary.

**Summary:** This article announces the release of a "Chaser Game" Season 2 side story episode titled "The Law of Positive and Negative," exploring the theme that gaining something requires losing somethingâ€”exemplified by President Nishikawa's dual reality of assuming CC4's presidency while facing life threats. The manga is serialized on Famitsu.com with the next episode scheduled for February 9, 2026, and Volume 14 is currently available for purchase. Coinciding with CyberConnect2's 30th anniversary, creator Hiroshi Matsuyama is releasing a "Game Industry Strategy Guide" on February 16, 2026, designed as a comprehensive resource for aspiring game industry professionals with interview tips and actual portfolios. The article also features current Amazon gaming sales rankings dominated by Minecraft and Roblox gift cards, along with links to related manga series and upcoming game releases.

ğŸ“ å…³é”®è¦ç‚¹ (6 sections)
  • Series Introduction: This is an article about 'Chaser Game' Season 2 Side Story episode titled 'The Law of Positive and Negative'. The manga is serialized on Famitsu.com and focuses on the theme 'to gain something, you must lose something'.
  • Editor's Commentary: The editor notes that the central theme 'to gain something, you must lose something' relates to the current storyline where President Nishikawa becomes CC4's president while his life is being threatened. The next episode will be published on February 9, 2026.
  • Volume 14 Availability: Volume 14 of 'Chaser Game' is available for purchase through Amazon.co.jp and Rakuten Books.
  • New Book Release: Hiroshi Matsuyama is releasing 'Game Industry Strategy Guide' on February 16, 2026, coinciding with CyberConnect2's 30th anniversary. The book serves as a new bible for game industry aspirants and includes job interview insights and actual portfolios from successful applicants.
  • Amazon Sales Rankings: The article displays current Amazon gaming sales rankings, predominantly featuring Minecraft and various Roblox gift cards in the top 5 positions.
  • Related Content Links: The page includes links to related manga series like 'Battlefield Fuga: Steel Melody' and other gaming articles, as well as upcoming game release schedules across multiple platforms.
